Description: Scarab in Egyptian blue, probably mould-made; underside decorated with two hieroglyphic signs, quite debased (possibly a Maat feather or yod sign to right and a red crown to left).
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Gardner (in Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 35). The scarab belongs to a type produced at the Scarab Factory (on this production, see Webb forthcoming) and widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Carthage, Kerkouan, Sicily and Gibraltar, but also in Greece, Cyprus and Rhodes (Gorton 1996, 118-121, type XXXIII, subtype A25-41, see especially A39 for this piece). See Hornung and Staehelin 1976, 402, MV 42 for a rather close parallel. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976. Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 119, Type XXXIII A39)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.53) (phase 3)
